2025 CA S 384
Author: Wahab
Version: Introduced
Version Date: 02/14/2025

CALIFORNIA LEGISLATURE--2025-2026 REGULAR SESSION

Senate Bill

No. 384

Introduced by Senator Wahab

February 14, 2025

An act to add Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) to Division 8 of the Business and Professions Code, relating to business.

LEGISLATIVE COUNSEL'S DIGEST

SB 384, as introduced, Wahab. Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act: prohibition on price-fixing algorithm use.

Existing law governs various business practices in this state, including certain laws relating to the use of technology.

This bill, the Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act, would prohibit a business from using a price-fixing algorithm, as defined, to set a price or supply level of a good or service. The bill would authorize the Attorney General or a city attorney or county counsel to file a civil action for violations of these provisions, as specified, including for a civil penalty of up to $1,000 per violation.

Vote Required: MAJORITY Appropriation: NO Fiscal Committee: YES Local Program: NO Immediate Effect NO Urgency: NO Tax Levy: NO Election: NO Usual Current Expenses: NO Budget Bill: NO Prop 25 Trailer Bill: NO

The people of the State of California do enact as follows:

SECTION 1. This act shall be known, and may be cited, as the Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act.

SEC. 2. Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) is added to Division 8 of the Business and Professions Code, to read:

40. Price-Fixing Algorithm

22949.85. (a) A business shall not use a price-fixing algorithm to set a price or supply level of a good or service.

(b) The Attorney General, in the name of the people of the State of California, or a city attorney or county counsel, in the name of the city or county, may file a civil action for a violation of this section for damages, injunctive relief, restitution, or civil penalties of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000) per violation, or any combination of those remedies. The court shall award reasonable attorney's fees and costs to the Attorney General, city attorney, or county counsel, as applicable, if they are the prevailing party in the action.

(c) For the purposes of this section, "price-fixing algorithm" means a software, system, or process that does both of the following:

(1) Collects historical or contemporaneous information on a price, price change, or supply level of a good or service from two or more persons or from public databases.

(2) Analyzes and processes the information described in paragraph (1).

(3) Creates pricing models based on the analyses and processing described in paragraph (2).

2025 CA S 384
Author: Wahab
Version: Amended
Version Date: 04/08/2025

AMENDED IN SENATE April 08, 2025

CALIFORNIA LEGISLATURE--2025-2026 REGULAR SESSION

Senate Bill

No. 384

Introduced by Senator Wahab

February 14, 2025

An act to add Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) to Division 8 of the Business and Professions Code, relating to business.

LEGISLATIVE COUNSEL'S DIGEST

SB 384, as amended, Wahab. Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act: prohibition on price-fixing algorithm use.

Existing law governs various business practices in this state, including certain laws relating to the use of technology.

This bill, the Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act, in addition to any other law, would prohibit a business seller, as defined, from using a price-fixing algorithm, as defined, to set either: (1) a price or supply level of a good or service. service or (2) a rent or occupancy level of rental property. The bill would authorize the Attorney General or a city attorney or county counsel to file a civil action for violations of these provisions, as specified, including for a civil penalty of up to $1,000 per violation.

Vote Required: MAJORITY Appropriation: NO Fiscal Committee: YES Local Program: NO Immediate Effect NO Urgency: NO Tax Levy: NO Election: NO Usual Current Expenses: NO Budget Bill: NO Prop 25 Trailer Bill: NO

The people of the State of California do enact as follows:

SECTION 1. This act shall be known, and may be cited, as the Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act.

SEC. 2. Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) is added to Division 8 of the Business and Professions Code, to read:

CHAPTER 40. Price-Fixing Algorithm

22949.85. (a) A business In addition to any other law, a seller shall not use a price-fixing algorithm to set a price either of the following:

(1) A price or supply level of a good or service.

(2) A rent or occupancy level of rental property.

(b) The Attorney General, in the name of the people of the State of California, or a city attorney or county counsel, in the name of the city or county, may file a civil action for a violation of this section for damages, injunctive relief, restitution, or civil penalties of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000) per violation, or any combination of those remedies. The court shall award reasonable attorney's fees and costs to the Attorney General, city attorney, or county counsel, as applicable, if they are the prevailing party in the action.

(c) For the purposes of this section, "price-fixing algorithm" section:

(1) "Artificial intelligence" means a machine-based system that can, for a given set of human-defined objectives, make predictions, recommendations, or decisions influencing real or virtual environments.

(2) "Nonpublic input data" means data that is competitively sensitive, including, but not limited to, price, output, customers, or sales territory.

(3) "Price-fixing algorithm" means a software, system, or process process, algorithmic program, or artificial intelligence that does both of the following:

(1) Collects historical

(A) Accepts the historical or contemporaneous information nonpublic input data of two or more sellers on a the price, price change, or supply level of a good or service or rent or occupancy level of rental property from two one or more persons or from public databases. sellers.

(2) Analyzes and processes the information

(B) Processes the nonpublic input data described in paragraph (1). subparagraph (A) for the purpose of producing a pricing or rental strategy.

(3) Creates pricing models based on the analyses and processing described in paragraph (2).

(4) (A) "Seller" means either of the following:

(i) A person or business entity who sells or leases a good or service to a consumer.

(ii) A landlord.

(B) "Seller" includes a person or a business entity that utilizes a price-fixing algorithm on behalf of a person or business described in subparagraph (A).

2025 CA S 384
Author: Wahab
Version: Amended
Version Date: 04/24/2025

AMENDED IN SENATE April 08, 2025

AMENDED IN SENATE April 24, 2025

CALIFORNIA LEGISLATURE--2025-2026 REGULAR SESSION

Senate Bill

No. 384

Introduced by Senator Wahab

February 14, 2025

An act to add Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) to Division 8 of the Business and Professions Code, relating to business.

LEGISLATIVE COUNSEL'S DIGEST

SB 384, as amended, Wahab. Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act: prohibition on price-fixing algorithm use.

Existing law governs various business practices in this state, including certain laws relating to the use of technology.

This bill, the Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act, in addition to any other law, would prohibit a person from selling, licensing, or otherwise providing and a seller, as defined, from using a price-fixing algorithm, as defined, to set either: (1) a price or supply level of a good or service or (2) a rent or occupancy level of rental property. The bill would provide a seller an affirmative defense to liability if the seller can show that the seller conducted due diligence, as specified. The bill would authorize the Attorney General or a city attorney or county counsel to file a civil action for violations of these provisions, as specified, including for a civil penalty of up to $1,000 per violation. violation, as specified.

Vote Required: MAJORITY Appropriation: NO Fiscal Committee: YES Local Program: NO Immediate Effect NO Urgency: NO Tax Levy: NO Election: NO Usual Current Expenses: NO Budget Bill: NO Prop 25 Trailer Bill: NO

The people of the State of California do enact as follows:

SECTION 1. This act shall be known, and may be cited, as the Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act.

SEC. 2. Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) is added to Division 8 of the Business and Professions Code, to read:

CHAPTER 40. Price-Fixing Algorithm

22949.85. (a) In addition to any other law, a person shall not sell, license, or otherwise provide and a seller shall not use a price-fixing algorithm to set either of the following:

(1) A price or supply level of a good or service.

(2) A rent or occupancy level of rental property.

(b) It shall be an affirmative defense to liability for a seller if the seller can show that the seller conducted due diligence and did not learn that using the price-fixing algorithm violated subdivision (a), including inquiring of the person selling, licensing, or providing the price-fixing algorithm whether the person was in violation of subdivision (a).

(c) (1) For a person who sells, licenses, or otherwise provides a price-fixing algorithm in violation of subdivision (a), each authorized user of, or user under a license for, the price-fixing algorithm constitutes a separate violation.

(2) For the purposes of a seller who uses a price-fixing algorithm in violation of subdivision (a), each calendar month of use constitutes a separate violation.

(b)

(d) The Attorney General, in the name of the people of the State of California, or a city attorney or county counsel, in the name of the city or county, may file a civil action for a violation of this section to recover actual damages or for damages, injunctive relief, restitution, or civil penalties of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000) per violation, or any combination of those remedies. The court shall award reasonable attorney's fees and costs to the Attorney General, city attorney, or county counsel, as applicable, if they are the prevailing party in the action.

(c)

(e) For the purposes of this section:

(1) "Artificial intelligence" means a machine-based system that can, for a given set of human-defined objectives, make predictions, recommendations, or decisions influencing real or virtual environments.

(1) "Artificial intelligence" means an engineered or machine-based system that varies in its level of autonomy and that can, for explicit or implicit objectives, infer from the input it receives how to generate outputs that can influence a physical or virtual environment.

(2) "Nonpublic input data" means data that is competitively sensitive, including, but sensitive to the seller and that the seller maintains in a confidential manner, but for allowing the data to be used in a price-fixing algorithm. "Nonpublic input data" may include, but is not limited to, price, output, customers, or sales territory.

(3) "Price-fixing algorithm" means a software, computer system, computer process, algorithmic program, or artificial intelligence that does both of the following:

(A) Accepts the historical or contemporaneous nonpublic input data of two or more sellers on the price, price change, or supply level of a good or service or rent or occupancy level of rental property from one or more sellers.

(B) Processes the nonpublic input data described in subparagraph (A) for the purpose of producing a pricing or rental strategy.

(4) (A) "Seller" means either of the following:

(i) A person or business entity who sells or leases a good or service to a consumer.

(ii) A landlord.

(B) "Seller" includes a person or a business entity that utilizes a price-fixing algorithm on behalf of a person or business described in subparagraph (A).

February 14, 2025

An act to add Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) to Division 8 of
the Business and Professions Code, relating to business.

LEGISLATIVE COUNSEL'S DIGEST

SB 384, as amended, Wahab. Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act:
prohibition on price-fixing algorithm use.

Existing law governs various business practices in this state, including
certain laws relating to the use of technology.

This bill, the Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act, in addition to any
other law, would prohibit a _person from selling, licensing, or otherwise
providing and a_ seller, as defined, from using a price-fixing algorithm, as
defined, to set either: (1) a price or supply level of a good or service or
(2) a rent or occupancy level of rental property._The bill would provide a
seller an affirmative defense to liability if the seller can show that the
seller conducted due diligence, as specified._ The bill would authorize the
Attorney General or a city attorney or county counsel to file a civil action
for violations of these provisions, as specified, including for a civil

Vote Required: MAJORITY Appropriation: NO Fiscal Committee: YES Local Program:
NO Immediate Effect NO Urgency: NO Tax Levy: NO Election: NO Usual Current
Expenses: NO Budget Bill: NO Prop 25 Trailer Bill: NO

The people of the State of California do enact as follows:

SECTION 1. This act shall be known, and may be cited, as the Preventing
Algorithmic Price Fixing Act.

SEC. 2. Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) is added to Division 8
of the Business and Professions Code, to read:

CHAPTER 40. Price-Fixing Algorithm

22949.85. (a) In addition to any other law, a _person shall not sell, license,
or otherwise provide and a_ seller shall not use a price-fixing algorithm to
set either of the following:

(1) A price or supply level of a good or service.

(2) A rent or occupancy level of rental property.

_(b) It shall be an affirmative defense to liability for a seller if the
seller can show that the seller conducted due diligence and did not learn that
using the price-fixing algorithm violated subdivision (a), including inquiring
of the person selling, licensing, or providing the price-fixing algorithm
whether the person was in violation of subdivision (a)._

_(c) (1) For a person who sells, licenses, or otherwise provides a price-
fixing algorithm in violation of subdivision (a), each authorized user of, or
user under a license for, the price-fixing algorithm constitutes a separate
violation._

_(2) For the purposes of a seller who uses a price-fixing algorithm in
violation of subdivision (a), each calendar month of use constitutes a
separate violation._

~~(b)~~

_(d)_ The Attorney General, in the name of the people of the State of
California, or a city attorney or county counsel, in the name of the city or
county, may file a civil action for a violation of this section _to recover
actual damages or_ for~~damages,~~ injunctive relief, restitution, or civil
penalties of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000) per violation, or any
combination of those remedies. The court shall award reasonable attorney's
fees and costs to the Attorney General, city attorney, or county counsel, as
applicable, if they are the prevailing party in the action.

~~(c)~~

_(e)_ For the purposes of this section:

~~(1) "Artificial intelligence" means a machine-based system that can, for a
given set of human-defined objectives, make predictions, recommendations, or
decisions influencing real or virtual environments.~~

_(1) "Artificial intelligence" means an engineered or machine-based system
that varies in its level of autonomy and that can, for explicit or implicit
objectives, infer from the input it receives how to generate outputs that can
influence a physical or virtual environment._

(2) "Nonpublic input data" means data that is competitively~~sensitive,
including, but~~ _sensitive to the seller and that the seller maintains in a
confidential manner, but for allowing the data to be used in a price-fixing
algorithm. "Nonpublic input data" may include, but is_ not limited to, price,
output, customers, or sales territory.

(3) "Price-fixing algorithm" means a software,_computer_ system,_computer_
process, algorithmic program, or artificial intelligence that does both of the
following:

(A) Accepts the historical or contemporaneous nonpublic input data of two or
more sellers on the price, price change, or supply level of a good or service
or rent or occupancy level of rental property from one or more sellers.

(B) Processes the nonpublic input data described in subparagraph (A) for the
purpose of producing a pricing or rental strategy.

(4) (A) "Seller" means either of the following:

(i) A person or business entity who sells or leases a good or service to a
consumer.

(ii) A landlord.

(B) "Seller" includes a person or a business entity that utilizes a price-
fixing algorithm on behalf of a person or business described in subparagraph
(A).

2025 CA S 384
Author: Wahab
Version: Amended
Version Date: 06/26/2025

AMENDED IN SENATE April 08, 2025

AMENDED IN SENATE April 24, 2025

AMENDED IN ASSEMBLY June 26, 2025

CALIFORNIA LEGISLATURE--2025-2026 REGULAR SESSION

Senate Bill

No. 384

Introduced by Senator Wahab

February 14, 2025

An act to add Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) to Division 8 of the Business and Professions Code, relating to business.

LEGISLATIVE COUNSEL'S DIGEST

SB 384, as amended, Wahab. Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act: prohibition on price-fixing certain price-setting algorithm use. uses.

Existing law governs various business practices in this state, including certain laws relating to the use of technology.

This bill, the Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act, in addition to any other law, would prohibit a person from selling, licensing, providing, or otherwise providing and a seller, as defined, from using a price-fixing price-setting algorithm, as defined, to with the intent that it be used by 2 or more competitors, as defined, in the same market if the person knows or should know that the algorithm processes nonpublic data, as defined, to set either: (1) a price or supply level of a good or service or (2) a rent or occupancy level of rental property. The bill would provide a seller person an affirmative defense to liability if the seller can show that the seller conducted person exercised reasonable due diligence, as specified. The bill would authorize the Attorney General or a district attorney, city attorney attorney, or county counsel to file a civil action for violations of these provisions, as specified, including for a civil penalty of up to $1,000 per violation, as specified.

Vote Required: MAJORITY Appropriation: NO Fiscal Committee: YES Local Program: NO Immediate Effect NO Urgency: NO Tax Levy: NO Election: NO Usual Current Expenses: NO Budget Bill: NO Prop 25 Trailer Bill: NO

The people of the State of California do enact as follows:

SECTION 1. This act shall be known, and may be cited, as the Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act.

SEC. 2. Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) is added to Division 8 of the Business and Professions Code, to read:

CHAPTER 40. Price-Fixing Price-Setting Algorithm

22949.85. (a) In addition to any other law, a A person shall not sell, license, provide, or otherwise provide and a seller shall not use a price-fixing price-setting algorithm with the intent that it be used by two or more competitors in the same market if the person knows or should know that the algorithm processes nonpublic input data to set either of the following:

(1) A price or supply level of a good or service.

(2) A rent or occupancy level of rental property.

(b) It shall be an affirmative defense to liability for a seller if the seller can show that the seller conducted due diligence and did not learn that using the price-fixing algorithm violated subdivision (a), including inquiring of the person selling, licensing, or providing the price-fixing algorithm whether the person was in violation of subdivision (a).

(b) It shall be an affirmative defense to liability for a person who demonstrates by clear and convincing evidence that they exercised reasonable due diligence, including obtaining written assurances from the person selling, licensing, or providing the algorithm that the algorithm does not process nonpublic input data.

(c) (1) For a person who sells, licenses, or otherwise provides a price-fixing price-setting algorithm in violation of subdivision (a), each authorized user of, or user under a license for, the price-fixing price-setting algorithm constitutes a separate violation.

(2) For the purposes of a seller person who uses a price-fixing price-setting algorithm in violation of subdivision (a), each calendar month of use constitutes a separate violation.

(d) The Attorney General, General or a district attorney, in the name of the people of the State of California, or a city attorney or county counsel, in the name of the city or county, may file a civil action for a violation of this section to recover actual damages or for injunctive relief, restitution, or civil penalties of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000) per violation, or any combination of those remedies. The court shall award reasonable attorney's fees and costs to the Attorney General, district attorney, city attorney, or county counsel, as applicable, if they are the prevailing party in the action.

(e) For the purposes of this section:

(1) "Artificial intelligence" means an engineered or machine-based system that varies in its level of autonomy and that can, for explicit or implicit objectives, infer from the input it receives how to generate outputs that can influence a physical or virtual environment.

(2) "Nonpublic input data" means data that is competitively sensitive to the seller and that the seller maintains in a confidential manner, but for allowing the data to be used in a price-fixing algorithm. "Nonpublic input data" may include, but is not limited to, price, output, customers, or sales territory. confidential, nonpublic, and sensitive information of competitors.

(3) "Price-fixing (A) "Price-setting algorithm" means a software, computer system, computer process, algorithmic program, or artificial intelligence that does both of the following:

(A) Accepts the historical or contemporaneous nonpublic input data of two or more sellers on the price, price change, or supply level of a good or service or rent or occupancy level of rental property from one or more sellers.

(B) Processes the processes nonpublic input data described in subparagraph (A) for the purpose of producing a pricing or rental strategy.

(B) "Price-setting algorithm" does not include a multiple listing service, as that term is defined in Section 1087 of the Civil Code.

(4) (A) "Seller" means either of the following:

(i) A person or business entity who sells or leases a good or service to a consumer.

(ii) A landlord.

(B) "Seller" includes a person or a business entity that utilizes a price-fixing algorithm on behalf of a person or business described in subparagraph (A).

(4) "Competitors" means two or more persons or business entities, including landlords, that offer similar or substitutable goods, services, or real property for lease in the same relevant market to the same or overlapping customer base.

---|---  
  
2025 CA S 384 | | Author: | Wahab  
---|---  
Version: | Amended  
Version Date: | 06/26/2025  
  
AMENDED IN SENATE April 08, 2025

AMENDED IN SENATE April 24, 2025

AMENDED IN ASSEMBLY June 26, 2025

CALIFORNIA LEGISLATURE--2025-2026 REGULAR SESSION

**Senate Bill**

**No. 384**

**Introduced by** Senator Wahab

February 14, 2025

An act to add Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) to Division 8 of
the Business and Professions Code, relating to business.

LEGISLATIVE COUNSEL'S DIGEST

SB 384, as amended, Wahab. Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act:
prohibition on~~price-fixing~~ _certain price-setting_ algorithm~~use.~~
_uses._

Existing law governs various business practices in this state, including
certain laws relating to the use of technology.

This bill, the Preventing Algorithmic Price Fixing Act,~~in addition to any
other law,~~ would prohibit a person from selling, licensing,_providing,_
or~~otherwise providing and a seller, as defined, from~~ using a~~price-
fixing~~ _price-setting_ algorithm, as defined,~~to~~ _with the intent that it
be used by 2 or more competitors, as defined, in the same market if the person
knows or should know that the algorithm processes nonpublic data, as defined,
to_ set either: (1) a price or supply level of a good or service or (2) a rent
or occupancy level of rental property. The bill would provide a~~seller~~
_person_ an affirmative defense to liability if the~~seller can show that the
seller conducted~~ _person exercised reasonable_ due diligence, as specified.
The bill would authorize the Attorney General or a _district attorney,_
city~~attorney~~ _attorney,_ or county counsel to file a civil action for
violations of these provisions, as specified, including for a civil penalty of
up to $1,000 per violation, as specified.

Vote Required: MAJORITY Appropriation: NO Fiscal Committee: YES Local Program:
NO Immediate Effect NO Urgency: NO Tax Levy: NO Election: NO Usual Current
Expenses: NO Budget Bill: NO Prop 25 Trailer Bill: NO

The people of the State of California do enact as follows:

SECTION 1. This act shall be known, and may be cited, as the Preventing
Algorithmic Price Fixing Act.

SEC. 2. Chapter 40 (commencing with Section 22949.85) is added to Division 8
of the Business and Professions Code, to read:

CHAPTER 40. ~~Price-Fixing~~ _Price-Setting_ Algorithm

22949.85. (a) ~~In addition to any other law, a~~ _A_ person shall not sell,
license,_provide,_ or~~otherwise provide and a seller shall not~~ use
a~~price-fixing~~ _price-setting_ algorithm _with the intent that it be used
by two or more competitors in the same market if the person knows or should
know that the algorithm processes nonpublic input data_ to set either of the
following:

(1) A price or supply level of a good or service.

(2) A rent or occupancy level of rental property.

~~(b) It shall be an affirmative defense to liability for a seller if the
seller can show that the seller conducted due diligence and did not learn that
using the price-fixing algorithm violated subdivision (a), including inquiring
of the person selling, licensing, or providing the price-fixing algorithm
whether the person was in violation of subdivision (a).~~

_(b) It shall be an affirmative defense to liability for a person who
demonstrates by clear and convincing evidence that they exercised reasonable
due diligence, including obtaining written assurances from the person selling,
licensing, or providing the algorithm that the algorithm does not process
nonpublic input data._

(c) (1) For a person who sells, licenses, or~~otherwise~~ provides a~~price-
fixing~~ _price-setting_ algorithm in violation of subdivision (a), each
authorized user of, or user under a license for, the~~price-fixing~~ _price-
setting_ algorithm constitutes a separate violation.

(2) For the purposes of a~~seller~~ _person_ who uses a~~price-fixing~~
_price-setting_ algorithm in violation of subdivision (a), each calendar month
of use constitutes a separate violation.

(d) The Attorney~~General,~~ _General or a district attorney,_ in the name of
the people of the State of California, or a city attorney or county counsel,
in the name of the city or county, may file a civil action for a violation of
this section to recover actual damages or for injunctive relief, restitution,
or civil penalties of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000) per violation, or
any combination of those remedies. The court shall award reasonable attorney's
fees and costs to the Attorney General,_district attorney,_ city attorney, or
county counsel, as applicable, if they are the prevailing party in the action.

(e) For the purposes of this section:

(1) "Artificial intelligence" means an engineered or machine-based system that
varies in its level of autonomy and that can, for explicit or implicit
objectives, infer from the input it receives how to generate outputs that can
influence a physical or virtual environment.

(2) "Nonpublic input data" means data that is~~competitively sensitive to the
seller and that the seller maintains in a confidential manner, but for
allowing the data to be used in a price-fixing algorithm. "Nonpublic input
data" may include, but is not limited to, price, output, customers, or sales
territory.~~ _confidential, nonpublic, and sensitive information of
competitors._

(3) ~~" Price-fixing ~~ _(A) "Price-setting _algorithm" means a software,
computer system, computer process, algorithmic program, or artificial
intelligence that~~does both of the following:~~

~~(A) Accepts the historical or contemporaneous nonpublic input data of two or
more sellers on the price, price change, or supply level of a good or service
or rent or occupancy level of rental property from one or more sellers.~~

~~(B) Processes the~~ _processes_ nonpublic input data~~described in
subparagraph (A)~~ for the purpose of producing a pricing or rental strategy.

_(B) "Price-setting algorithm" does not include a multiple listing service, as
that term is defined in Section 1087 of the Civil Code._

~~(4) (A) "Seller" means either of the following:~~

~~(i) A person or business entity who sells or leases a good or service to a
consumer.~~

~~(ii) A landlord.~~

~~(B) "Seller" includes a person or a business entity that utilizes a price-
fixing algorithm on behalf of a person or business described in subparagraph
(A).~~

_(4) "Competitors" means two or more persons or business entities, including
landlords, that offer similar or substitutable goods, services, or real
property for lease in the same relevant market to the same or overlapping
customer base._
